articles.headline: Fighting Surges and Deaths Rise as Israel Drives Deeper in Gaza
articles.snippet: Israeli troops and Palestinian militants waged their most intense battles since Israel re-entered Gaza last week.
articles.abstract: Israeli troops and Palestinian militants waged their most intense battles since Israel re-entered Gaza last week.
articles.lead_paragraph: BEIT LAHIYA, Gaza Strip, Friday, July 7 — A member of Hamas was reported killed in an airstrike Friday, less than 24 hours after Israeli troops and Palestinian militants had waged their most intense battles since Israel re-entered the Gaza Strip last week to secure the release of a captured soldier and stop rocket fire into Israel.
articles.byline: By Steven Erlanger and Greg Myre

articles.headline: Jump-Start or New Battery for G.M.?
articles.snippet: Directors of General Motors are scheduled to meet Friday to discuss whether to open talks on a three-way alliance involving G.M., Renault and Nissan.
articles.abstract: Directors of General Motors are scheduled to meet Friday to discuss whether to open talks on a three-way alliance involving G.M., Renault and Nissan.
articles.lead_paragraph: DETROIT, July 6  What would Carlos Ghosn bring to the table?

articles.headline: Conservative Wins in Mexico in Final Tally
articles.snippet: Felipe Calderón's opponent said he would demand a recount after the tally showed a margin of 243,000 votes.
articles.abstract: Felipe Calderón's opponent said he would demand a recount after the tally showed a margin of 243,000 votes.
articles.lead_paragraph: MEXICO CITY, July 6 — After days of uncertainty, election officials declared Thursday that Felipe Calderón, a conservative, had won the race for president by less than 1 percent of the official count. His leftist rival refused to accept the results and vowed to go to court and demand a recount.
articles.byline: By James C. McKinley Jr. and Ginger Thompson

articles.headline: Can a Failure Become a Savior?
articles.snippet: Does it make sense for General Motors to be rescued by Renault, a company that has failed repeatedly in its efforts to sell cars to Americans?
articles.abstract: Does it make sense for General Motors to be rescued by Renault, a company that has failed repeatedly in its efforts to sell cars to Americans?

articles.headline: Algerian Tells of Dark Term in U.S. Hands
articles.snippet: The tale of Laid Saidi has never been told before, and it carries a new set of allegations against the U.S.'s rendition program.
articles.abstract: The tale of Laid Saidi has never been told before, and it carries a new set of allegations against the U.S.'s rendition program.
articles.lead_paragraph: ALGIERS — Two years ago, a motley collection of prisoners spent night after night repeating their telephone numbers to one another from within the dark and dirty cells where they were being held in Afghanistan. Anyone who got out, they said they agreed, would use the numbers to contact the families of the others to let them know that they were still alive.
articles.byline: By Craig S. Smith and Souad Mekhennet

articles.headline: Brazil's Oil Giant Is Drilling Far From Home Waters
articles.snippet: When Petróleo Brasileiro, Brazil's state-controlled energy company, said it would not spend another cent investing in Bolivia after the nationalization of the energy sector there, it was no idle threat.      Petrobras, a company that once bartered...
articles.abstract: When Petróleo Brasileiro, Brazil's state-controlled energy company, said it would not spend another cent investing in Bolivia after the nationalization of the energy sector there, it was no idle threat.      Petrobras, a company that once bartered chickens for imported oil, used to focus solely on guaranteeing the supply of fuel for Brazil, Latin America's biggest economy, with 180 million people.
articles.lead_paragraph: MACAÉ, Brazil - When Petróleo Brasileiro, Brazil's state-controlled energy company, said it would not spend another cent investing in Bolivia after the nationalization of the energy sector there, it was no idle threat.

articles.headline: Strategy Shift by Microsoft to Fight iPod
articles.snippet: Microsoft's interest in making its own hand-held music and video player, disclosed by entertainment industry executives this week, indicates that its old way of doing things is not working in its battle against Apple Computer's iPod.      In the P...
articles.abstract: Microsoft's interest in making its own hand-held music and video player, disclosed by entertainment industry executives this week, indicates that its old way of doing things is not working in its battle against Apple Computer's iPod.      In the PC market, its bread and butter, Microsoft has depended on hundreds of large and small computer makers that have built desktop and laptop computers running its Windows operating system.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO, July 6 - Microsoft's interest in making its own hand-held music and video player, disclosed by entertainment industry executives this week, indicates that its old way of doing things is not working in its battle against Apple Computer's iPod.

articles.headline: Algerian Tells of Dark Term in U.S. Hands
articles.snippet: Two years ago, a motley collection of prisoners spent night after night repeating their telephone numbers to one another from within the dark and dirty cells where they were being held in Afghanistan. Anyone who got out, they said they agreed, wou...
articles.abstract: Two years ago, a motley collection of prisoners spent night after night repeating their telephone numbers to one another from within the dark and dirty cells where they were being held in Afghanistan. Anyone who got out, they said they agreed, would use the numbers to contact the families of the others to let them know that they were still alive.     At least two of those men are now free and, thanks to the memorization exercise, are back in touch with each other.
articles.lead_paragraph: ALGIERS - Two years ago, a motley collection of prisoners spent night after night repeating their telephone numbers to one another from within the dark and dirty cells where they were being held in Afghanistan. Anyone who got out, they said they agreed, would use the numbers to contact the families of the others to let them know that they were still alive.
articles.byline: By Craig S. Smith and Souad Mekhennet

articles.headline: Conservative Wins in Mexico in Final Tally
articles.snippet: After days of uncertainty, election officials declared Thursday that Felipe Calderón, a conservative, had won the race for president by less than 1 percent of the official count. His leftist rival refused to accept the results and vowed to go to c...
articles.abstract: After days of uncertainty, election officials declared Thursday that Felipe Calderón, a conservative, had won the race for president by less than 1 percent of the official count. His leftist rival refused to accept the results and vowed to go to court and demand a recount.     As he pulled ahead in a tally overnight that entranced the nation, Mr. Calderón said he would fight to keep his victory, however narrow, over the populist former Mexico City mayor, Andrés Manuel López Obrador. Election officials said Mr. Calderón had won by 243,000 votes out of 41 million cast on Sunday.
articles.lead_paragraph: MEXICO CITY, July 6 - After days of uncertainty, election officials declared Thursday that Felipe Calderón, a conservative, had won the race for president by less than 1 percent of the official count. His leftist rival refused to accept the results and vowed to go to court and demand a recount.
articles.byline: By James C. McKinley Jr. and Ginger Thompson

articles.headline: Fighting Surges and Deaths Rise as Israel Drives Deeper in Gaza
articles.snippet: A member of Hamas was reported killed in an airstrike Friday, less than 24 hours after Israeli troops and Palestinian militants had waged their most intense battles since Israel re-entered the Gaza Strip last week to secure the release of a captur...
articles.abstract: A member of Hamas was reported killed in an airstrike Friday, less than 24 hours after Israeli troops and Palestinian militants had waged their most intense battles since Israel re-entered the Gaza Strip last week to secure the release of a captured soldier and stop rocket fire into Israel.     The death toll had risen throughout Thursday in sometimes fierce fighting involving everything from rifles to airborne missiles.
articles.lead_paragraph: BEIT LAHIYA, Gaza Strip, Friday, July 7 - A member of Hamas was reported killed in an airstrike Friday, less than 24 hours after Israeli troops and Palestinian militants had waged their most intense battles since Israel re-entered the Gaza Strip last week to secure the release of a captured soldier and stop rocket fire into Israel.
articles.byline: By Steven Erlanger and Greg Myre

articles.headline: Jump-Start or New Battery for G.M.?
articles.snippet: What would Carlos Ghosn bring to the table?     It is a top-of-mind question for directors of General Motors, who are scheduled to meet Friday to discuss whether to open talks on a three-way alliance involving G.M. and the two companies that Mr. G...
articles.abstract: What would Carlos Ghosn bring to the table?     It is a top-of-mind question for directors of General Motors, who are scheduled to meet Friday to discuss whether to open talks on a three-way alliance involving G.M. and the two companies that Mr. Ghosn runs, Renault and Nissan.
articles.lead_paragraph: DETROIT, July 6 - What would Carlos Ghosn bring to the table?

articles.headline: Can a Failure Become a Savior?
articles.snippet: GENERAL MOTORS is in trouble for a lot of reasons, but a major one is the difficulty it has had in competing in the American market with automakers from Germany, Japan and South Korea. So does it really make sense for it to be rescued by Renault, ...
articles.abstract: GENERAL MOTORS is in trouble for a lot of reasons, but a major one is the difficulty it has had in competing in the American market with automakers from Germany, Japan and South Korea. So does it really make sense for it to be rescued by Renault, a French company that has failed repeatedly in its efforts to sell cars to Americans?     Here in Paris, there is some doubt whether Carlos Ghosn, who runs both Renault and Nissan of Japan, could really handle another job, as Kirk Kerkorian, G.M.'s largest shareholder, seems to want. ''The United States is different,'' said one French executive, speaking privately. ''When would he sleep?''
articles.lead_paragraph: PARIS - GENERAL MOTORS is in trouble for a lot of reasons, but a major one is the difficulty it has had in competing in the American market with automakers from Germany, Japan and South Korea. So does it really make sense for it to be rescued by Renault, a French company that has failed repeatedly in its efforts to sell cars to Americans?

articles.headline: Big Award on Tobacco Is Rejected by Court
articles.snippet: Tobacco companies in the United States won a major legal victory yesterday when the Florida Supreme Court upheld a decision to toss out a $145 billion judgment against them.     The ruling, in what is one of the last remaining personal injury clas...
articles.abstract: Tobacco companies in the United States won a major legal victory yesterday when the Florida Supreme Court upheld a decision to toss out a $145 billion judgment against them.     The ruling, in what is one of the last remaining personal injury class-action cases against tobacco companies, is a crushing blow to plaintiffs' lawyers, who have pushed for large class-action cases with the potential for multibillion-dollar verdicts. The six-judge Florida court stated that smokers' cases ''are highly individualized'' and ''do not lend themselves to class-action treatment."
articles.lead_paragraph: Tobacco companies in the United States won a major legal victory yesterday when the Florida Supreme Court upheld a decision to toss out a $145 billion judgment against them.
